00020 #ifndef           STRNGS_H
00021 #define           STRNGS_H
00022 
00023 #include          <string.h>
00024 #include          "memry.h"
00025 #include          "serialis.h"
00026 #include          "genericvector.h"
00027 
00028 // STRING_IS_PROTECTED means that  string[index] = X is invalid
00029 // because you have to go through strings interface to modify it.
00030 // This allows the string to ensure internal integrity and maintain
00031 // its own string length. Unfortunately this is not possible because
00032 // STRINGS are used as direct-manipulation data buffers for things
00033 // like length arrays and many places cast away the const on string()
00034 // to mutate the string. Turning this off means that internally we
00035 // cannot assume we know the strlen.
00036 #define STRING_IS_PROTECTED  0
00037 
00038 #ifdef CCUTIL_EXPORTS
00039 #define CCUTIL_API __declspec(dllexport)
00040 #elif defined(CCUTIL_IMPORTS)
00041 #define CCUTIL_API __declspec(dllimport)
00042 #else
00043 #define CCUTIL_API
00044 #endif
00045 
00046 
00047 class DLLSYM STRING
00048 {
00049   public:
00050     STRING();
00051     STRING(const STRING &string);
00052     STRING(const char *string);
00053     ~STRING ();
00054 
00055     // Writes to the given file. Returns false in case of error.
00056     bool Serialize(FILE* fp) const;
00057     // Reads from the given file. Returns false in case of error.
00058     // If swap is true, assumes a big/little-endian swap is needed.
00059     bool DeSerialize(bool swap, FILE* fp);
00060 
00061     BOOL8 contains(const char c) const;
00062     inT32 length() const;
00063     inT32 size() const { return length(); }
00064     const char *string() const;
00065 
00066 #if STRING_IS_PROTECTED
00067     const char &operator[] (inT32 index) const;
00068     // len is number of chars in s to insert starting at index in this string
00069     void insert_range(inT32 index, const char*s, int len);
00070     void erase_range(inT32 index, int len);
00071 #else
00072     char &operator[] (inT32 index) const;
00073 #endif
00074     void split(const char c, GenericVector<STRING> *splited);
00075     void truncate_at(inT32 index);
00076 
00077     BOOL8 operator== (const STRING & string) const;
00078     BOOL8 operator!= (const STRING & string) const;
00079     BOOL8 operator!= (const char *string) const;
00080 
00081     STRING & operator= (const char *string);
00082     STRING & operator= (const STRING & string);
00083 
00084     STRING operator+ (const STRING & string) const;
00085     STRING operator+ (const char ch) const;
00086 
00087     STRING & operator+= (const char *string);
00088     STRING & operator+= (const STRING & string);
00089     STRING & operator+= (const char ch);
00090 
00091     // Appends the given string and int (as a %d) to this.
00092     // += cannot be used for ints as there as a char += operator that would
00093     // be ambiguous, and ints usually need a string before or between them
00094     // anyway.
00095     void add_str_int(const char* str, int number);
00096 
00097     // ensure capcaity but keep pointer encapsulated
00098     inline void ensure(inT32 min_capacity) { ensure_cstr(min_capacity); }
00099 
00100   private:
00101     typedef struct STRING_HEADER {
00102       // How much space was allocated in the string buffer for char data.
00103       int capacity_;
00104 
00105       // used_ is how much of the capacity is currently being used,
00106       // including a '\0' terminator.
00107       //
00108       // If used_ is 0 then string is NULL (not even the '\0')
00109       // else if used_ > 0 then it is strlen() + 1 (because it includes '\0')
00110       // else strlen is >= 0 (not NULL) but needs to be computed.
00111       //      this condition is set when encapsulation is violated because
00112       //      an API returned a mutable string.
00113       //
00114       // capacity_ - used_ = excess capacity that the string can grow
00115       //                     without reallocating
00116       mutable int used_;
00117     } STRING_HEADER;
00118 
00119     // To preserve the behavior of the old serialization, we only have space
00120     // for one pointer in this structure. So we are embedding a data structure
00121     // at the start of the storage that will hold additional state variables,
00122     // then storing the actual string contents immediately after.
00123     STRING_HEADER* data_;
00124 
00125     // returns the header part of the storage
00126     inline STRING_HEADER* GetHeader() {
00127       return data_;
00128     }
00129     inline const STRING_HEADER* GetHeader() const {
00130       return data_;
00131     }
00132 
00133     // returns the string data part of storage
00134     inline char* GetCStr() {
00135       return ((char *)data_) + sizeof(STRING_HEADER);
00136     };
00137 
00138     inline const char* GetCStr() const {
00139       return ((const char *)data_) + sizeof(STRING_HEADER);
00140     };
00141     inline bool InvariantOk() const {
00142 #if STRING_IS_PROTECTED
00143       return (GetHeader()->used_ == 0) ?
00144         (string() == NULL) : (GetHeader()->used_ == (strlen(string()) + 1));
00145 #else
00146       return true;
00147 #endif
00148     }
00149 
00150     // Ensure string has requested capacity as optimization
00151     // to avoid unnecessary reallocations.
00152     // The return value is a cstr buffer with at least requested capacity
00153     char* ensure_cstr(inT32 min_capacity);
00154 
00155     void FixHeader() const;  // make used_ non-negative, even if const
00156 
00157     char* AllocData(int used, int capacity);
00158     void DiscardData();
00159 };
00160 #endif
